skos.definition: Serum calcium concentration (corrected for albumin) below 8.5 mg/dL or ionized calcium below 4.5 mg/dL, causing neuromuscular irritability, cardiac conduction abnormalities, and in severe cases, tetany and seizures.
skos.scopeNote: Must always correct for albumin level; ionized calcium is the gold standard

content.title: Hypocalcemia
content.summary: Hypocalcemia is low serum calcium (corrected <8.5 mg/dL or ionized <4.5 mg/dL), commonly caused by hypoparathyroidism, vitamin D deficiency, or chronic kidney disease. It presents with neuromuscular irritability (tetany, paresthesias, Chvostek/Trousseau signs) and cardiac effects (prolonged QT). Severe symptomatic hypocalcemia requires IV calcium.
key_points: Always correct total calcium for albumin: add 0.8 mg/dL for each 1 g/dL albumin below 4
Ionized calcium is the physiologically active form and gold standard
Common causes: hypoparathyroidism, vitamin D deficiency, CKD, hypomagnesemia
Chvostek sign: facial twitch with tapping; Trousseau sign: carpal spasm with BP cuff
ECG: prolonged QT interval (risk of torsades de pointes)
IV calcium gluconate for severe/symptomatic; oral calcium + vitamin D for chronic
Must correct hypomagnesemia for calcium replacement to be effective
content.statement: Hypocalcemia results from decreased PTH, vitamin D deficiency, tissue deposition, or chelation of calcium. Clinical manifestations reflect increased neuromuscular excitability due to lowered threshold for action potential generation. Treatment targets both symptom relief and correction of the underlying cause.

explanation.intuition: Calcium acts as a 'stabilizer' of nerve and muscle cell membranes. When calcium is low, the threshold for nerve firing drops, making neurons and muscles hyperexcitable. This is why patients get tingling, muscle spasms, and even seizures - the cells are too 'trigger-happy' and fire too easily.
explanation.key_insight: The PTH-vitamin D axis is central to understanding hypocalcemia. PTH mobilizes calcium from bone, increases renal reabsorption, and stimulates vitamin D activation. Vitamin D enhances intestinal calcium absorption. Disruption anywhere in this axis (parathyroid surgery, vitamin D deficiency, CKD) causes hypocalcemia.
explanation.technical_details: Calcium exists in three forms: ionized (50%, physiologically active), albumin-bound (40%), and complexed to anions (10%). pH affects binding - alkalosis increases albumin binding, reducing ionized calcium (explaining post-hyperventilation tetany). PTH acts on bone (osteoclast activation) and kidney (calcium reabsorption, phosphate excretion, 1-alpha-hydroxylase activation). Active vitamin D (1,25-dihydroxy) primarily increases intestinal calcium absorption.

definitions_glossary.ionized_calcium: Physiologically active free calcium; not bound to albumin or anions; gold standard measurement
definitions_glossary.corrected_calcium: Total calcium adjusted for albumin: Corrected Ca = measured Ca + 0.8 × (4 - albumin)
definitions_glossary.Chvostek_sign: Facial muscle twitch when tapping facial nerve anterior to ear; present in ~10% of normals
definitions_glossary.Trousseau_sign: Carpal spasm when BP cuff inflated above systolic for 3 minutes; more specific than Chvostek
definitions_glossary.tetany: Involuntary muscle contractions due to hypocalcemia; can affect hands, feet, larynx
definitions_glossary.hypoparathyroidism: Decreased PTH production; most common cause is post-thyroidectomy
definitions_glossary.vitamin_D_deficiency: Inadequate 25-OH vitamin D; common in elderly, malabsorption, limited sun exposure
definitions_glossary.hungry_bone_syndrome: Rapid calcium uptake by bone after parathyroidectomy for hyperparathyroidism
definitions_glossary.pseudohypoparathyroidism: PTH resistance; high PTH but low calcium; associated with Albright hereditary osteodystrophy
definitions_glossary.acute_pancreatitis: Fat saponification binds calcium; hypocalcemia is poor prognostic sign
definitions_glossary.citrate: Blood product anticoagulant that chelates calcium; massive transfusion can cause hypocalcemia
definitions_glossary.prolonged_QT: ECG finding in hypocalcemia; risk of torsades de pointes
definitions_glossary.calcium_gluconate: IV calcium preparation preferred peripherally; less irritating than calcium chloride
definitions_glossary.calcium_chloride: Contains 3× more elemental calcium but highly irritating; requires central access

pathophysiology.mechanism: Hypocalcemia develops from decreased PTH, decreased vitamin D, or calcium deposition/chelation. Low ionized calcium increases sodium channel permeability, lowering the threshold for depolarization and causing neuromuscular hyperexcitability.

PTH_related: Severe hypomagnesemia (inhibits PTH secretion and action)

symptoms: Perioral and acral paresthesias (tingling around mouth, fingers, toes)
signs: Trousseau sign (carpal spasm with BP cuff)

laboratory_testing: Total calcium and albumin (calculate corrected calcium)
Phosphate (high in hypoparathyroidism, low in vitamin D deficiency)
Magnesium (must correct for calcium treatment to work)

interpretation.low_Mg: Hypomagnesemia - impairs both PTH secretion and action

diagnostic_criteria.ecg: Always obtain to assess QT interval

acute_symptomatic.treatment: Calcium gluconate 10% 10-20 mL (1-2 g) IV over 10-20 minutes
acute_symptomatic.infusion: Follow with continuous infusion: 10 g calcium gluconate in 1L D5W at 50-100 mL/hr
acute_symptomatic.monitoring: Check ionized calcium every 4-6 hours during infusion
acute_symptomatic.caution_digoxin: Calcium potentiates digoxin toxicity - give slowly with cardiac monitoring

chronic_management.oral_calcium: Calcium carbonate or citrate 1-3 g/day in divided doses
chronic_management.vitamin_D: Calcitriol 0.25-2 mcg/day (active form) or ergocalciferol for deficiency
chronic_management.goal: Low-normal calcium (8-9 mg/dL) to avoid hypercalciuria and renal stones
chronic_management.monitoring: Calcium, phosphate, 25-OH vitamin D, urinary calcium

correct_hypomagnesemia.rationale: Magnesium is required for PTH secretion and action
correct_hypomagnesemia.treatment: IV magnesium sulfate 2-4 g, then oral replacement

hypoparathyroidism: Lifelong calcium and active vitamin D replacement
PTH analog (Natpara - recombinant PTH) in refractory cases
Avoid thiazide diuretics (reduce urinary calcium excretion)

prognosis.acute: Excellent with appropriate IV calcium replacement
prognosis.chronic: Requires lifelong monitoring and replacement in hypoparathyroidism

learning_objectives: Calculate corrected calcium from total calcium and albumin
Recognize clinical signs of hypocalcemia (Chvostek, Trousseau, tetany)
Differentiate causes of hypocalcemia using PTH and phosphate levels
Describe the role of magnesium in calcium homeostasis
Outline emergency treatment of severe symptomatic hypocalcemia
Explain the PTH-vitamin D axis in calcium regulation
clinical_pearls: Always correct calcium for albumin - low albumin causes false 'hypocalcemia'
Ionized calcium is the only reliable measure in critically ill patients
Post-thyroidectomy hypocalcemia peaks at 24-72 hours - watch closely
Hungry bone syndrome after parathyroidectomy can cause severe, prolonged hypocalcemia
Magnesium must be repleted for PTH secretion and calcium replacement to work
Hyperventilation causes tetany through alkalosis-induced decrease in ionized calcium

high_yield_topics: PTH and phosphate to diagnose cause
common_question_stems: Patient with CKD and secondary hyperparathyroidism
Alcoholic with tetany and low Mg
exam_tips: High PTH + low phos = vitamin D deficiency
Always correct Ca for albumin: +0.8 per 1 g/dL albumin below 4
Trousseau is more specific than Chvostek

teaching_cases.scenario: 56-year-old woman 2 days after total thyroidectomy presents with perioral tingling and hand cramping. Ca 6.9, albumin 4.0, Mg 1.8, phos 5.2, PTH 8.
teaching_cases.key_findings: Low calcium, low PTH, high phosphate, positive Trousseau sign
teaching_cases.management: IV calcium gluconate, start oral calcium and calcitriol, monitor closely

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on BMJ clinical review and NEJM reference on hypoparathyroidism
